etymologies: late 15th century (earlier (late Middle English) as suffocation): from Latin suffocat- ‘stifled’, from the verb suffocare, from sub- ‘below’ + fauces ‘throat’

definitions: die or cause to die from lack of air or inability to breathe

examples.text: she was suffocated by the fumes

shortDefinitions: die or cause to die from lack of air or inability to breathe

definitions: have or cause to have difficulty in breathing

examples.text: he was suffocating, his head jammed up against the back of the sofa
you're suffocating me—I can scarcely breathe

shortDefinitions: have or cause to have difficulty in breathing

definitions: feel or cause to feel trapped and oppressed

examples.text: he said he'd suffocate if he remained in this house for another hour

shortDefinitions: feel or cause to feel trapped and oppressed
